Joel Lehman and I are pleased to announce two new papers to appear at the C=
EC and GECCO conferences that both extend and analyze novelty search and it=
s applicability:

(1) "Evolving a Diversity of Virtual Creatures through No=
velty Search with Local Competition"
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_=
gecco11.pdf
Abstract: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/lehman.gecc=
o11.html

(2) "Improving Evolvability through Novelty Search and Self-Adapt=
ation"
http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_cec11.pdf
Abstract: http://epl=
ex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/lehman.cec11.html

These papers fit well wi=
th the recent discussion on this group that wrestled with the role of fitne=
ss in nature and its implications for EC.  The first paper reveals an impor=
tant insight into how novelty search can be combined most effectively with =
a more traditional objective.  Many have suggested making novelty in effect=
 one objective and fitness in effect another in a multiobjective context.  =
However, this paper shows that there is a big downside to having a global o=
bjective, even when combined with novelty search, because it precludes all =
kinds of interesting niches that are not necessarily competitive at being g=
lobally optimal.  Instead, the paper proposes that objective competition in=
 the presence of novelty search should only be among *similar* individuals =
(i.e. it should be "local").  That way, through the combination of novelty =
search and competition, numerous interesting and diverse niches proliferate=
 in a single run, which is an important goal artificial life systems.  In f=
act, this approach can produce wide ranges of competent artificial creature=
s in just one run that past such experiments would have taken numerous runs=
 to produce.  A video montage from a single run is here: http://eplex.cs.uc=
f.edu/ns/vc.html


The second paper shows how removing objectives impacts e=
volvability.  If you think about it, this result is intuitive:  If evolutio=
n selects for behavioral novelty, then lineages that are good at producing =
such novelty (i.e. evolvable lineages) will be favored.  The paper further =
shows that self-adaptation, which has been popular yet sometimes performed =
disappointingly in the EA literature, works much better under novelty searc=
h than under objective-driven search, in part because of selection for evol=
vability. 

I think ultimately where the evidence is pointing is not that n=
ovelty search in its pure form is the answer to every problem, but rather t=
hat novelty search is itself an important stepping stone to a variety of mo=
re exotic approaches that treat the objective in nontraditional ways with i=
nteresting implications.
